Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2016 10:14PM 1vamom wrote: Hello, I am new to this as well. I found out in January I am Stage 4, with mets to spine, liver, and mainly lungs. Lungs have been the worst, as I am tied to an oxygen line I can't escape. I luckily have lots of "family support," but am still at a total loss as to where to start thinking this thru. And actually feel completely alone, and like I would do my family the biggest favor by just getting "out of their way" quickly. I have been in chemo since January, with most of an idea about the "plan," but still feel completely out of control of EVERYTHING. I don't have much faith in counseling, am a pretty private soul, and have met before the one counselor I believe is provided by my insurance co, and really wasn't impressed. I am in such a fog, am completely energy-free and lethargic, and end up wondering why I am not "doing better" at this, for lack of a better term. Also, feeling awful for feeling so awful, as my conditions could be a million times worse than I feel like they actually are, when I take the true measure of it all. Such a back and forth, and up and down from day-to-day. Then figure that is to be expected, and the cycle starts anew. I really just can't seem to get much of a grip on any of it, or how I feel about any of it, or how I should feel, or anything else... Recent chemo (Gemzar) seems to be doing it's job, and I think it's driving me nuts just sitting around from week to week waiting, or whatever it is I am doing. Thanks for listening, I don't really have anyone who just wants to listen to me cry. Reading back, all I think is geez what a whiner, and try to tell myself that's o.k. I have a great cat who's totally freaked out by it all...
Posts.Title: I'm new. Antonietta1647 Laflint

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 04:45PM 1vamom wrote: Please, let them have a look. I spent several years(!) not wanting to waste anyone's time with what I thought was an infected milk duct.  Turns out I have cancer, and now am facing chemo to try and shrink this lump before they operate, which I probably wouldn't have had to do before.  Not trying to scare you into anything, and best of luck tomorrow, but please don't feel like you are wasting anyone's time with anything that concerns you.  Again, best of luck tomorrow, and every woman here hopes you are just wasting time and that this will turn out to be nothing.
Posts.Title: Am i being silly? michelleb Fabulicious_Mami

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 03:19AM 1vamom wrote: I don't even know my stage, as, due to complications, I haven't been able to have surgery, yet. I would never dream of offering medical advice, as I am not a doctor. But to think that my good wishes would not only be ignored, but they would offend someone? Why are my thoughts,fears, and good wishes not respected because I have not been at this as long? Aren't those who have gone before us those we are here to learn from? Barbe had it right with sand box mentality.  I feel like I'm in high school and at the wrong lunch table.  Sorry to any I've offended in my quest for knowledge about this disease we share, and I'll sign off 'til I know my place.
Posts.Title: RESPECTING the STAGE threads **RANT** cherneski Nico1012

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 04:06AM 1vamom wrote: So, since I don't know my stage, I should just head elsewhere till I know where I "fit in?' And shouldn't look to any of you "Stagers" for information? I don't see a category for "Had a really crappy miscarriage at the start of all this, now can't start Chemo till my blood levels are better, and can't have any surgery until Chemo is done, but still freaked out, and looking for information i could possibly use later" I think this is incredibly selfish, not to realize that if you post here, someone is going to come along looking for info and may possibly peek into someone else's threads. But, that said, I absolutely respect anyone's need to privacy and respect. So, if I am seeking knowledge, I will stick to basic threads, and not worry about, or comment on, anyone's cancer that is "worse" than mine.
Posts.Title: RESPECTING the STAGE threads **RANT** cherneski Nico1012

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 04:25PM 1vamom wrote: Maybe it just scares them, I don't know, but my fiance (and best friend)  has been distant and angry with me since my diagnosis right before xmas.  I relayed on another post how, in my first meeting with the oncologist, he (this is a quick reenactment) said, "All I know is my band played in her bar, 2 weeks later she was knocked up, now here we are." When he had to make a trip to the bathroom in the midddle of the conversation about my chemotherapy, the doctor asked what was wrong with him, and said his body language gave off the impression of "disinterest."  I made excuses for him, and said he was just scared.  He also will not look at any info I have been given, and, while is usually on webmd for anything from a cold to, well, anything, I don't get the impression he has any interest in this.  I, too, have heard whatever I want, it's just fine with him.  What I want is for him to take some interest in this, and behave like an adult.  He has been short with everyone in the housee, and snappy with me.  To the point I told him to forget it, I would visit this site and take my comfort from strangers.  He left for work this morning without us saying a word.  We have a 3-year-old who knows something is up, but not what, and I have been trying to be extra cheerful for her.  But sometimes I need to go lie in bed and cry, and at one point he told her, "Mommy is just grumpy right now."  Sorry for posting so long, but this is driving me nuts, and if you, Eszcriibe, are just close to nuts, you're forgiven by me!  Feel free to message me to talk, to rant, or just to hear, "I know JUST how you feel."  I Do.
Posts.Title: Stand by Her - What guys need to know, and do standbyher mspores

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2010 11:53PM 1vamom wrote: 40, but had felt a lump for several years. I thought it was just irritated milk ducts from breast-feeding, and then put off a mammogram for several years, because I "didn't have the time." Now, I am hoping chemo will shrink this so I can save part of my breast, but I don't know much right now.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 05:23PM 1vamom wrote: Hi all, I'm all for a good rant now and again! My role is stay-at-home mom of a 3 1/2 year old girl, and everyone knows this means chocolates and magazines on the couch all day!  I, too, don't get a lot of help, prefer to do things myself anyway, and bitch like the devil when the load gets too hard.  Why should you feel "crazy" if it just gets to the point where you really can't take any more?  Where's the help everyone promised?  I am cranky almost to the point where I can't stand myself.  But how to deal with the fact that this is IT?
